title: Costa Rica - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: UNDECA: National Union of Employees of the Fund and Social Security; ANDE: National Association of Educators; APSE: Association for Secondary School Teachers; Labour Group (Costa Rica); Teachers (Costa Rica); Health Workers (Costa Rica)

On 4 February 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, members of National Union of Employees of the Fund and Social Security (UNDECA), National Association of Educators (ANDE), Association for Secondary School Teachers (APSE), National Union of Nursing (SINAE), and other unions demonstrated in front of the Legislative Assembly against the planned salary reform for the public employment sector. [size=no report]
On 31 January 2021, in San Rafael, Cartago, an unspecified number of armed men shot and killed a man in a residential area. The victim was employed at the Social Security Office of Costa Rica (CCSS).
On 26 January 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, police officers staged a protest demanding better labour conditions and salary raises. [size=no report]

On 25 January 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, farmers, including members of the Farmers of the North Zone of Cartago, occupied the Inter-American Court of Human Rights as part of a protest to demand better labour conditions for the agriculture sector. [size=no report]

On 21 January 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, a group of Nicaraguan citizens, who fled their government's persecution in 2018 to seek asylum in Costa Rica, demonstrated in front of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) offices to demand support with finding employment, medical treatment, and registration in the social security system. [size=no report]
Health Workers (Costa Rica); Labour Group (Costa Rica)

On 21 January 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, 110 employees of the hospital Calderon Guardia, including nurses and cleaning workers, demonstrated in front of the social security administration to demand that they be vaccinated against the coronavirus. [size=110]

On 6 January 2021, in San Jose, San Jose, Nicaraguan protesters gathered in front of the Honduran Embassy to demand investigations and justice for the recent killing of a Nicaraguan commander in Honduras. [size=no report]

On 27 December 2020, in Puntarenas (Puntarenas), community members rioted against police presence, attacking them with coups, rocks and other objects to express dissatisfaction against the police operation in the area. Two police officers were lightly injured. [size=no report]
On 21 December 2020, in San Jose (San Jose), thirty informal street sellers protested to demand the municipal police to stop street control which have hampered their activities. [size=30]

Around 19 December 2020 (as reported), in San Jose (San Jose), transportation workers staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Transportation and Public Works demanding the renewal of their licenses, suspended for ten months amidst the coronavirus crisis. [size=no report]
Around 18 December 2020 (as reported), in Siquirres (Limon), a man was shot and killed on a banana farm. Motive and perpetrators unknown.
On 15 December 2020, in Puntarenas (Puntarenas), community members from Coto Brus protested against the lack of water provision. [size=no report]
On 10 December 2020, in San Francisco de Dos Rios (San Jose), a lawyer involved in a gang-related court case was shot and injured by two men on a motorcycle. Motive and perpetrators unknown.

On 9 December 2020, in San Jose (San Jose), the Costa Rican Association of Fairground Workers protested in front of the Ministry of Health demanding the resumption of economic activities amidst the coronavirus crisis as they need to work to guarantee their livelihoods. [size=no report]

On 8 December 2020, in Concepcion (Cartago), around 30 protesters gathered in front of the house of the President of Congress. Protesters demanded the president of congress to go against a governmental bill that sets provisions for a deal with International Monetary Fund and tax increases. Protesters also gathered against the Law of Waters (motive unclear). [size=around 30]
On 8 December 2020, in San Jose (San Jose), garbage collectors protested against the privatization of garbage collection in the municipality. [size=no report]

Around 6 December 2020 (as reported), on the road between San Ramon and San Carlos (Alajuela), rioters allegedly attacked people and cars as they tried to set a roadblock as part of a demonstration. Motive unknown. They had wood sticks and stones with which they tried to attack civilians and police officers. Police intervened with unspecified chemical agents to disperse the rioters. One person was detained. [size=no report]

On 16 September 2018, in Buenos Aires, Puntarenas, a labor union group protested to reject the tax reform law. No further specifications. [size=no report]
On 16 September 2018, in Pococi, Limon, a labor union group protested to reject the tax reform law. No further specifications. [size=no report]
On 16 September 2018, at the Plantel de Recope in Cartago, a labor union group protested to reject the tax reform law. No further specifications. [size=no report]
On 16 September 2018, in Canas, Guanacaste, a labor union group protested to reject the tax reform law. No further specifications. [size=no report]

On 15 September 2018, in Barranca, Puntarenas, dozens of people protested against the Fiscal Reform Law. It is reported that the vehicular passage has been interrupted and riot police moved to the area to control the protest. [size=dozens]
On 15 September 2018, a peaceful protest was carried out from Alto de Ochomogo to Cartago as part of the strike that is being carried out against the project to strengthen public finances.
On 15 September 2018, a peaceful protest was held in San Jose as part of the strike that is being carried out against the project to strengthen public finances.

On 21 September 2018, a protest was registered in Cartago because Costa Ricans are on strike against fiscal reforms. With lanterns, flags, balloons and posters, a group of protesters shouted ''No to the fiscal combo, ''No to the fiscal combo'' and ''General strike against the fiscal combo'' while agents of the Public Force guarded the perimeter of the Municipal Palace.
On 14 September 2018, members of the Association of Teachers of Secondary Education joined the march and the strike against the tax reform.

On 13 September 2018, students from the University of Costa Rica demonstrated on the San Jose bypass road. Students and a journalist were assaulted by members of the Public Force. This protest was motivated by violent attacks in front of the church San Pedro de Montes de Oca and the University of Costa Rica.
Students (Costa Rica); Civilians (Costa Rica); Journalists (Costa Rica)

On 13 September 2018, several journalists received blows, threats, insults and obstacles during the marches against the tax reform. The transmissions by television channels were hampered by a group of demonstrators, among them university students, during the march that left the University of Costa Rica towards the Presidential House in the capital, San Jose.

On 13 September 2018, a 17-year-old boy was killed during the riots that took place in the place known as Santa Eduviges de Limon. The boy was shot in the head, while another teenager was shot in the leg. It was not clear whether the boys were involved in the riots.

On 12 September 2018, in Limon (Limon), rioters tried to burn a bus with passengers inside during a demonstration. Police intervened and the bus was liberated. Motive of the riot unknown.[size=no report]

On 12 September 2018, violent attacks were reportedly performed by demonstrators in front of the Church San Pedro de Montes de Oca and the University of Costa Rica in San Jose. The motives of these acts are unknown.
On 12 September 2018, thousands of people marched in the streets of San Jose to demand that the president of Costa Rica reject a tax reform proposal before Congress that includes new taxes.
On 11 September 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), protesters marched against the tax reform law proposal. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2018, in Limon (Limon), protesters tried to block the exit of the Recope, the Costa Rican Petroleum Refiner, against the tax reform law proposal. Police intervened, including with a small tank to disperse protesters. No reports of injuries. [size=no report]
On 11 September 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), a car crashed into protesters intentionally. Motive of the protest unknown, reports of small injuries. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2018, in Limon, a group of people blocked streets with fire and burning waste on the public highway. It is reported that firefighters and police officers had to move to the area. The reason for the demonstration is not reported. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2018, in Alajuela, a group of people blocked streets with fire and burning waste on the public highway. It is reported that firefighters and police officers had to move to the area. The reason for the demonstration is not reported. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2018, people from the municipality of San Jose joined the national strike to show their anger over the approval of the Fiscal Plan. As a form of protest, demonstrators blocked the street that is behind the municipal building. The act prevented also prevented a train from passing. Also, there was a blockade on several highways where health officials joined the demonstration and the strike against taxes.
On 8 September 2018, a the demonstration was held in San Jose against child violence.

On 5 September 2018, in Palmar del Norte, a group of people protested because residents of the area have been affected by the chemical Nemagon. It is reported that the chemical was used in banana plantations in the country and was banned 32 years ago. Protesters claimed payment for damages caused by this chemical such as abortions, cancer, and genetic malformations. [size=no report]
On 3 September 2018, a group of people marched in the San Jose streets against the immigrants coming from neighbouring Nicaragua.
On 31 August 2018, in Limon (Limon), protesters demanded politicians to fulfil their campaign promises, especially to fix a dike. [size=no report]
On 31 August 2018, in Limon (Limon), dockers protested to demand the payment of late salaries. [size=no report]
On 28 August 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), cab drivers protested against the Uber platform in front of the Presidential house. [size=no report]

On 28 August 2018, a group of television journalists was attacked with stones and by a group of demonstrators, in the town of Barranca, Puntarenas. The actions occurred when several subjects approached to the journalists, to reprimand them and prevent them from advancing. Apparently, the people who carried out the attack are part of the fishing guild of Puntarenas.

On 28 August 2018, the fishing guild of Puntarenas completely blocked an avenue in protest against the government, which, according to the protesters, still does not listen to them in their petitions about trawling, among other issues.
On 27 August 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), farmers protested for the elimination of the IVA, the Tax on Aggregated Value in the agricultural sector. [size=no report]

On 26 August 2018, students and organizations defending human rights marched in San Jose to show their support for Nicaraguan migrants. The rally was called after a demonstration against migrants held in the Costa Rican capital ended in clashes and the arrest of more than 40 people. [size=no report]

Around 19 August 2018 (as reported), in San Jose (San Jose), rioters demonstrated against Nicaraguans in exile in Costa Rica. 44 persons were detained during what was reported as a violent demonstration without giving further details. [size=at least 44]

On 18 August 2018, a group of protesters approached La Merced Park in San Jose to demand actions to stop the constant migration of Nicaraguans to the national territory. Protesters shouted ''Fuera nicas'' and ''Costa Rica respects itself'', and asked that something be done about the irregular situation of the Nicaraguans. Another group came to ask for respect. Public Forces had to intervene to try to stop violent acts and separate both sides. The event ended in clashes and the arrest of more than 40 people.

On 18 August 2018, in San Jose, the Costa Rica Coalition group protested against xenophobia and the rejection of Nicaraguans in Costa Rica. It is reported that Coalition Costa Rica celebrates the support provided from different institutions and organizations to those fleeing Nicaragua. [size=no report]

On 12 August 2018, dozens of Nicaraguans demonstrated in San Jose in a vigil to remember those who were killed in the midst of the sociopolitical crisis that Nicaragua is currently going through and to repudiate the government of Daniel Ortega. With Nicaraguan flags and banners, the Nicaraguans, many of them self-exiled to Costa Rica, shouted slogans against Ortega's government, accusing it of ''killing'', ''corrupting'' and keeping political protesters as political prisoners.
On 12 August 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), union workers and students protested in front of the Congress against the tax reform law. [size=no report]

On 11 August 2018, a group of women protested in the Plaza de la Cultura in San Jose to repudiate gender violence and machismo. The protest took place in the framework of a vigil in honor of the two killed tourists.

On 8 August 2018, several people from Puntarenas area held a peaceful vigil three days after the killing of a tourist. Residents, while demanding justice and more security, held banners and wore white shirts in peace.
On 8 August 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), 52 pro-choice organizations protested for the right to safe abortion. They gathered in front of the Presidential house. [size=no report]
On 4 August 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), six organizations protested against abortion. [size=no report]

On 4 August 2018, hundreds of people demonstrated in the Plaza de la Justicia, in the center of San Jose, to ask the judges to approve homosexual marriage in Costa Rica. With music, multicolored flags and posters, advocates of same-sex marriage demanded a positive resolution.

On 28 July 2018, the Chinese community in Limon marched through the main streets of the center of the province in protest of the wave of crime that crosses the area and of which they feel direct victims.
On 13 July 2018, in San Jose, 30 public employees have protested after the decision of the Court to apply a molestation to four magistrates for dismissing evidence in a judicial case. [size=30]
On 4 July 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), cab drivers protested against the Uber platform. [size=no report]

On 3 July 2018, taxi drivers protested in the streets of San Jose, traffic police officers responded and tried to regulate the passage of drivers. In front of the Presidential House, the road remains totally closed due to the presence of at least one thousand taxi drivers.

On 1 July 2018, a diversity march was held in San Jose in which there were calls for respect, equality and the guarantee of the human rights of the LGBTQ+ population. Thousands of people walked through the main avenues of San Jose with slogans in favor of equality, multicolored flags, and advocating respect for the human rights of all people.
ANEP: National Association of Public and Private Employees; Labour Group (Costa Rica)

On 25 June 2018, 2018, in front of the Constitutional Chamber in San Jose, dozens of municipal workers, including representatives of the National Association of Public and Private Employees (ANEP), protested against the tax reform presented by the president. It is reported that the exit of an individual armed with a rifle from the Constitutional Chamber generated discomfort among the protesters. [size=dozens]
ANEP: National Association of Public and Private Employees; Labour Group (Costa Rica)
On 18 June 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), union workers from ANEP, the National Association of Public and Private Employees, protested against the price of tolls and other costs. [size=no report]

On 10 June 2018, in San Jose, 150 people protested to ask for the exit of president Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua. It is reported that protesters showed their indignation about the current political situation in Nicaragua. [size=150]

On 6 June 2018, 018, in San Jose (San Jose), fishermen protested for the second consecutive day, demanding subsidies during the suspension of the fishing season and that they be allowed to fish shrimp during such seasons. [size=no report]

On 5 June 2018, a group of fishermen arrived at the Presidential House in San Jose to demonstrate peacefully and request a meeting with the president. Protesters asked for more employment opportunities since large companies are monopolizing the market.

On 29 May 2018, police officers seized 166 packages of cocaine weighing approximately 1.5-2.5 kilograms each in Los Angeles of Grecia in Alajuela. The drug belonged to a group linked to El Chapo cartel (Sinaloa) in Mexico. It is reported that four cars were also seized. Six Mexicans and one Guatemalan were arrested.
On 21 May 2018, San Jose (San Jose), Venezuelan people protested against the election results in Venezuela. [size=no report]

On 16 May 2018, at the Atlantico station, San Jose, representatives of the National Taxi Union (UNT) protested against the private platform Uber. The group of taxi drivers insisted that they have worked legally and the government has ignored their rights. [size=no report]

On 11 May 2018, drivers of a private company protested against the reduction of different items of their salaries, which they consider unjustified. Protesters appealed to freedom of association, to be given better conditions, and to have no restrictions on the money that goes into their families. The exact place of this protest is unknown.
On 9 May 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), around 20 persons protested against the regime of President Ortega in front of the Nicaraguan Embassy . [size=around 20]
On 8 May 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), protesters gathered at the Supreme Court to protest against the increase of femicides around the country. [size=no report]

On 8 May 2018, the president of Bolivia, Evo Morales, arrived outside the National Theater in San Jose to participate in an official lunch. At that moment, a small group of protesters arrived to demand freedom in Nicaragua and Daniel Ortega's departure from power. The South American leader did not want to get out of the car and asked for reinforcement from the police.

On 2 May 2018, a group of taxi drivers protested outside the Constitutional Chamber to demonstrate once again against the technological application of Uber. About 150 taxi drivers gathered in the area of calle Moreno in San Jose to declare Uber's activities illegal.
On 27 April 2018, in Atenas (Alajuela), community members protested against the lack of adequate water provision for the affected communities. [size=no report]
On 25 April 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), distinct union members and others marched to protest against the tax reform proposal. [size=no report]

On 20 April 2018, residents of various areas in Cartago blocked two lanes from a route that connects the city of Paraiso with Cartago. The protests began against the construction of a motel in the vicinity of the shopping mall.

On 20 April 2018, political leaders and other Costa Rican civil organizations protested in support of Nicaraguans who are protesting in the neighboring country against reforms to the pension system announced by the government. The protest took place outside the Nicaraguan Embassy in San Jose and a group of Nicaraguans participated in the protest. [size=no report]
On 18 April 2018, traffic police officers protested and blocked roads in San Jose, demonstrating about the breaches in the payment of their salaries.
On 17 April 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), 35 protesters gathered in front of the Legislative Assembly to protest against so-called luxury pensions. [size=35]

On 16 April 2018, a group of parents from a school in Heredia put a chain on the entrance to the school in protest against a kindergarten teacher. According to protesters, at least 8 children have been attacked by a teacher at this school.
On 13 April 2018, in Limon 2000 (Limon), a group of over 50 students protested to demand more university partnerships for internship opportunities. [size=over 50]
On 13 April 2018, in Limon (Limon), university students marched to protest against the lack of international partnerships at the University of Costa Rica. [size=no report]

On 5 April 2018, in Quepos, a group of health workers protested in a hospital because the general director will be transferred to another center. Protesters recognize the positive changes this director has brought to the hospital. [size=no report]

On 4 April 2018, around Heredia (Heredia), 40 workers from the National Council of Persons Living with Disabilities protested against the vulnerable state of persons living with disabilities around the country. [size=40]
On 1 April 2018, 6 women from a feminist movement demonstrated peacefully in a polling place to draw attention to the dangerous of a fundamentalist religious government for the country. [size=6]
On 21 March 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), around a hundred cab drivers protesters against Uber drivers in the country. [size=around 100]

On 19 March 2018, a group of indigenous people from Alta Talamanca went out to protest the poor state of the roads that lead to their community. For that reason, they closed the passage by the bridge of Hone Creek in this locality.
ANIC: National Association of Investigators in Criminalistics

On 9 March 2018, in San Jose, a group of people, including representatives of the National Association of Investigators in Criminalistics (ANIC), protested in favor of the attorney general. It is reported that protesters support the attorney general given the actions taken in certain criminal cases. [size=no report]
On 6 March 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), athletes marched to demand the immediate hiring of professional coaches due to delay in the selection procedure. [size=no report]

On 26 February 2018, different sectors of the fishing area in Puntarenas blocked a main route in the sector, so that traffic in the area was interrupted. The protest was comprised of fishermen demanding the granting of licenses, expressing their opinion on export regulations, and calling for the improvement of the economy of the area and sustainable development.
On 19 February 2018, about 200 people closed a main road at the entrance of Limon as a measure of protest for the poor state of the school in the area.

On 19 February 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), rangers protested against the Ministry of Environment and Energy and the National System for Environmental Conservation Areas for not fulfilling previously made promises. [size=no report]

On 15 February 2018, a group of workers closed in the morning several entries from the University of Costa Rica in Montes de Oca, San Jose as a protest for the lack of an agreement on the issue of annuities.
On 13 February 2018, in Ciudad Quesada (Alajuela), family members of students blocked three schools to protest against evidence-based sex education for students. [size=no report]
On 13 February 2018, a presidential candidate held a demonstration with a group of people outside a television channel in La Sabana, downtown San Jose, saying he is ready to debate any issue.
On 13 February 2018, in Buenos Aires (Puntarenas), family members of students blocked a school to protest against evidence-based sex education for students. [size=no report]

On 12 February 2018, a group of protesters in San Carlos received the Minister of Education who went to the region to try to resolve some of the parents' doubts about the Affectivity and Comprehensive Sexuality programs in schools.
On 9 February 2018, in Ciudad Quesada (Alajuela), family members of students blocked many schools in the city to protest against evidence-based sex education for students . [size=no report]
On 8 February 2018, in Perez Zeledon municipality, family members of students blocked many schools in the city to protest against evidence-based sex education for students. [size=no report]
On 8 February 2018, in San Carlos municipality, Alajuela, family members of students blocked many schools in the city to protest against evidence-based sex education for students. [size=no report]
On 8 February 2018, in Limon (Limon), family members of students blocked many schools in the city to protest against evidence-based sex education for students. [size=no report]

Around 8 February 2018 (as reported), in San Rafael de Guatuso (Alajuela), protesters closed an education center to protest against the government's decision to provide evidence-based education on sexuality to students .[size=no report]

Around 8 February 2018 (as reported), in Upala (Alajuela), protesters closed an education center to protest against the government's decision to provide evidence-based education on sexuality to students .[size=no report]

On 4 February 2018, a group of women dressed in clothes that covered most of their bodies to protest against what they consider a fundamentalist threat. According to the group of women, the protest was intended to draw attention to a society in which women have lost all their rights, due to a religious regime that uses them only to have children. The protest was held in a polling place in a school in Heredia.

On 24 January 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), patients protested at the Mexico Hospital demanding that the sector of organ transplants remains open after hearing it would be terminated. [size=no report]

On 20 January 2018, people from different civil society groups marched in the center of San Jose to demand a secular state. The march began in the Central Park and ended on the outskirts of the Legislative Assembly. Other motives behind for the march were demanding respect for religious groups and against deputies who have made discriminatory comments against the gay population of Costa Rica.

On 13 January 2018, outside Channel 7 and 6 in San Jose, the president of the National Restoration party and followers protested to demand that its candidacy be taken into account in the debates that the media will conduct. [size=no report]

On 9 January 2018, a plaza in San Pedro de Montes de Oca, became the meeting point for members of the LGBT community. At least 300 people celebrated the decision of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, which ordered the government of the Republic to recognize the legal rights of the LGTBQ community, including the right to marriage.

On 8 January 2018, outside the Constitutional Chamber in San Jose, 200 fishermen protested to reject the vote that imposed the expiration of fishing licenses in Puntarenas. It is reported that most fishermen were left without permission to fish and without work. [size=200]
On 6 January 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), animal defenders protested against bull fights and for animal's rights. [size=no protest]
On 1 January 2018, in San Jose (San Jose), Uber drivers protested in front of the Presidential House. Motive unknown. [size=no report]
